text: Family Member: Potassium. Doctor: Oh. Patient: Potassium and antibiotics. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Oh, your potassium is off. They came back two days later and said, oh, it was a little off. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Potassium was a little off. Doctor: Okay. We’ll, we’ll check you out for that. You know? You’re here because when Dr. S___, he did the lung biopsy or at least he told those guys to do a lung biopsy, it shows prostate cancer in your lungs. So not lung cancer. So in some sense a little bit of a relief but you still have your cancer of the – Patient: Of the prostate. Doctor: - prostate in your lungs. Now, you had that in twenty sixteen. It’s just that there’s more of it and slightly bigger. So that’s why I got you. When I went to, I sent you to Dr. S___, it was like well what are we going to do? Well, I need to take a sample. So he thought about going down this way. If you remember to try to get a sample from that, but he thought getting it through the outside would be just fine. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side?

text: Family Member: and then a trial opens up does he just jump to the trial? Doctor: No. Oh, you got to date it, Sorry. Patient: Oh, I’m sorry. Doctor: I can’t even date it for you. It has to be you. Yeah. Um, Uh, If it’s working we don’t bail out, only if it’s not working, but we will have, you know, the trials are like a moving target so if there’s something that pops up and I think that you would benefit then yes, we would make that opportunity. So, I’m always aware of what’s up here which is why I pulled you guys back to say there’s nothing here that is anything other than chemo but now as we’re thinking about this I’ll know, you know, by this week, okay, that’s a lie because this is Thursday, Family Member: It’s Thursday Doctor: by next week, what two trials make sense based on you know what’s happening. You know, the hard part about those chemo trials is there is a group that only gets the chemo. I like that because everybody gets chemo. Family Member: It’s the placebo thing? Doctor: Right. So, it’s placebo in the sense that the new drug is not guaranteed but it’s not placebo in the sense everybody gets chemo. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So, if there’s, you know, you’re guy one and you’re guy two you both get chemo no matter what. You might get drug and you might not. Patient: I got you, okay. Doctor: One of them you know. The other one you don’t. So, some it’s like oh, I’m just gonna get stuff infused in but we all kind of go gee, I wonder and it becomes a topic every time. The nurses try to guess. Everybody tries to guess. No one knows the answer except the people who actually hold the key. And then the other one is you know whether you get it or not because they just tell you okay, you’re just getting the chemo. But, the difference is you know everybody gets the chemo. That’s your standard drug. Nobody gets gipped out of that.

text: Patient: Well, well, I guess what I’m asking, if my PSA stays down - Doctor: The standard of care is – Patient: We should do nothing. Doctor: Is continue just doing what we’re doing. Patient: Eve—even, not even the clinical trial? Doctor: Right. One of the reasons for that has to do with, you know, how do we evaluate you on a clinical trial? What are our markers? PSA level? Patient: If, if, if, if – Doctor: So, if the hormones alone are making those get better, better, better, we give you the trial, I have no way to know did it do anything. So, we usually wait until the hormone stops working by itself. Family Member: And, that’s all just gauged by a PSA or do you do the – Doctor: It’s gauged by PSA as a screening and then, you know, at some point we would then just re-image you, too. Family Member: Hmm. Doctor: But, our experience is, as long as the PSA’s going down, usually the imaging is either getting better or staying stable. So.

Doctor: Is continue just doing what we’re doing. Patient: Eve—even, not even the clinical trial? Doctor: Right. One of the reasons for that has to do with, you know, how do we evaluate you on a clinical trial? What are our markers? PSA level? Patient: If, if, if, if – Doctor: So, if the hormones alone are making those get better, better, better, we give you the trial, I have no way to know did it do anything. So, we usually wait until the hormone stops working by itself. Family Member: And, that’s all just gauged by a PSA or do you do the – Doctor: It’s gauged by PSA as a screening and then, you know, at some point we would then just re-image you, too. Family Member: Hmm. Doctor: But, our experience is, as long as the PSA’s going down, usually the imaging is either getting better or staying stable. So.

text: Family Member: Yeah, uh hum. Doctor: We know a lot about the side effects. Family Member: Well with having chemotherapy, would that be, I know it’s not the same drug, but the same effect like I had chemotherapy for breast cancer? Doctor: Yes, we use one drug. We use Taxotere. So I don’t which ones you got. Family Member: I had Adriamycin and Cytoxan. Doctor: Yeah, it’s a little bit different. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: We think it’s probably a little bit better tolerated because we’re only giving one drug Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: than it is you know the hair loss, the nausea, the vomiting, Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: you know the numbness of the fingertips, excess tearing, you know changes in blood counts, that you’re at risk for infection, can cause liver injury, nausea, things that you feel

text: Patient: No, I’ve just seen my regular doctor. Family Member: He just told me. He was hiding it from me. Doctor: Ah. text: Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we talked about an MRI which would tell us more about your back to see if there's something in the middle of the bone that would be cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or we could look at a PET scan, which you know, PSA is over point seven. These PET scans can be pretty good about picking up things. And basically they're just looking at how tumors are growing and if they’re growing, then they light up. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that we can do one of those scans and see how much lights up. Usually what…I don't like these tests because they tend to find what's under the radar. Because we know there's disease- Patient: Right. Doctor: -because you have had surgery. You have had radiation? Patient: Oh yeah. Healthcare Professional: Mhmm. Doctor: So you've got a PSA, you've got disease. So knowing where it is doesn't necessarily help me now. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: We have my father-in-law, Dr. ____ on the phone. Doctor: Okay, hi R____. Family Member: Hi, good morning. Doctor: Yeah, so uh, uh, I think you met them all before. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: and so welcome back, unfortunately. (chuckles) Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So you uh, we went through uh the you know clinical trial and you went to surgery, and uh when they did the surgery uh you had some lymph nodes uh that popped up, and we uh wanted to get a better sense of using the special PSMA scan, uh what was going on, where there was cancer left. And so we had to do the scan, and uh the good news is we found prostate cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, and uh the bad news is we found prostate cancer, but we sort of knew it was there. Patient: Right. Doctor: And and what we saw on the scan basically is in your pelvis here, from here down to where the prostate was there’s still a lot of lymph nodes with prostate cancer in them. The good news is we didn’t see any higher; so it sort of ends at the pelvis, and we didn’t see any in the bones.

text: Family Member: So continue with the Lupron, and every four months is what she gets us. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So what’s, what’s the deal at the (coughs) Doctor: Well, the trial is done. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
